sub_subject.name: Historical Skills & Methods
sub_subject.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Historical Skills & Methods (History & Social Studies)

objectives.objective_text: Identify a letter from a long time ago (Primary).
Name a history book (Secondary).
Identify the date a document was created.
Identify a 'long time ago'.
Name a decade as ten years.
Identify things that stay the same (families, eating).
Name things that change (toys, clothes).
Identify traditions that we still keep today.
Name the President or King.
Identify the current year.
Name 'Before Christ' (BC) and 'Anno Domini' (AD).
Identify people changing the rules.
Name the American Revolution (freedom).
Identify the 'Age of Revolutions'.
Identify a King who wants more land.
Name the Roman Empire.
Identify the Spanish Empire in the Americas.
Identify swapping toys.
Name the Silk Road.
Identify the Hanseatic League or Mediterranean trade.
Identify moving house.
Name the Pilgrims moving to America.
Identify the Irish Potato Famine migration.
Identify 'Because'.
Name what happened next.
Identify unintended consequences.
Identify what is the same (we eat bread).
Name what is different (we drive cars).
Identify a Turning Point.
Identify a famous person.
Name a big event.
Identify bias in a source.
Identify that people see things differently.
Name two sides to a fight.
Identify propaganda.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Corroboration and Cross-Referencing (The Rule of Witnesses)
objectives.objective_text: Name 'Witnesses' as people who saw it.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Corroboration and Cross-Referencing (The Rule of Witnesses)
objectives.objective_text: Identify points of agreement and disagreement.
Identify if the writer likes or hates the subject.
Name "Unfair" stories.
Identify emotional words used to trick us.
Name the author.
Identify a forgery or fake.
Identify 'Ancient Times' (sandals/swords).
Recall that an eyewitness sees it happen.
Observe an old coin or tool.
Recall that grandparents lived before I was born.
Recall that people have always needed God.
Observe that houses look different now.
Recall the time of Knights and Castles.
Observe that the world changes.
Recall that kings pass the crown to their children.
Observe a family tree.
Recall that we count up from Jesus' birth.
Recall that sometimes fighting happens to make things fair.
Observe the French flag (Tricolor).
Recall that empires grow and then shrink.
Observe maps changing colors.
Recall that spices were very expensive.
Observe ships carrying boxes.
Recall that people move for food or safety.
Observe different cultures in one city.
Recall dominos falling.
Observe that actions have results.
Recall that people always sin and love.
Observe clothes changing over time.
Recall why we celebrate July 4th.
Observe statues of important people.
Recall that enemies tell different stories.
Observe that not everything in books is true.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Corroboration and Cross-Referencing (The Rule of Witnesses)
objectives.objective_text: Recall that the Bible says "by the mouth of two or three witnesses."

objectives.sub_topic_name: Corroboration and Cross-Referencing (The Rule of Witnesses)
objectives.objective_text: Observe that sometimes stories don't match.
Recall that everyone has a reason for writing.
Observe pictures that make a leader look like a superhero.
Recall that we need to know where a book came from.
Observe that some papers are copies of copies.
Name 'Modern Times' (cars/phones).
Explain primary sources (letters/diaries) vs. secondary sources (books).
Summarize the difference between being there and hearing about it.
Explain why we trust a diary more than a movie.
Categorize sources as Primary or Secondary.
Explain the limitations of secondary sources.
Defend the necessity of going "Ad Fontes" (to the sources).
Explain why numbers go backward in BC years.
Count how many years old I am.
Explain what a 'Century' (100 years) and 'Millennium' (1000 years) are.
Explain 'circa' (approximate dating).
Defend the accuracy of biblical genealogies for estimating eras.
Summarize how farming has changed but eating hasn't.
Explain 'Progress' (getting better at technology).
Explain why some cultures change faster than others.
Defend the biblical view of human nature as the ultimate continuity.
Explain why we group years together.
Categorize a picture into the correct time period.
Explain the 'Dark Ages' myth vs. reality.
Defend alternative periodization models (e.g., Technology driven).
Order pictures of a story: First, Next, Last.
Summarize the order of US Presidents (First few).
Explain what a 'Dynasty' is (family of rulers).
Sequence the major wars of US history.
Explain 'Concurrent' events (happening at the same time).
Defend the importance of knowing the sequence to understand cause.
Order three pictures from oldest to newest.
Summarize the timeline of major biblical events (Creation to Christ).
Place 5 historical events in correct sequence.
Explain the concept of an 'Era' or 'Epoch'.
Defend the historical centrality of the Incarnation.
Summarize the causes of the American vs. French Revolution.
Explain the Industrial Revolution (machines).
Explain the Digital Revolution.
Defend the concept of ordered liberty vs. chaos.
Summarize the rise and fall of Rome.
Explain the British Empire ('Sun never sets').
Explain the Ottoman Empire.
Defend the distinction between colonization and conquest.
Summarize how the Silk Road connected East and West.
Explain the Triangle Trade (Slavery).
Explain Globalization.
Defend the role of trade in preventing war.
Summarize the Great Migration (Out of Africa / Into Americas).
Explain the Jewish Diaspora (scattered people).
Explain the Refugee crisis.
Defend the biblical mandate to care for the sojourner.
Summarize why WWI started (The assassination).
Explain the difference between a trigger and a long-term cause.
Explain counterfactual history ('What if?').
Defend the role of human agency vs. determinism.
Summarize how life changed after the printing press.
Explain that some things change fast (revolution) and some slow (evolution).
Explain the concept of 'Periodization'.
Defend the immutability of human nature.
Summarize why we remember Lincoln.
Explain 'History is written by the victors'.
Defend the historicity of the Resurrection as the most significant event.
Summarize how the British view the Revolution vs. Americans.
Explain 'Bias' (liking one side more).
Explain the danger of anachronism.
Defend the pursuit of objective truth in history.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Corroboration and Cross-Referencing (The Rule of Witnesses)
objectives.objective_text: Ask two friends what happened to see if they say the same thing.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Corroboration and Cross-Referencing (The Rule of Witnesses)
objectives.objective_text: Summarize why we need more than one source.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Corroboration and Cross-Referencing (The Rule of Witnesses)
objectives.objective_text: Explain how to check if a story is true.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Corroboration and Cross-Referencing (The Rule of Witnesses)
objectives.objective_text: Explain the danger of a "Single Source" history.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Corroboration and Cross-Referencing (The Rule of Witnesses)
objectives.objective_text: Defend the biblical standard of evidence in history and law (Deut 19:15).
Summarize what the author wants you to believe.
Explain "Bias" (leaning to one side).
Explain censorship and omission (what is left out).
Defend the pursuit of objective truth while acknowledging subjectivity.
Ask "Who wrote this?".
Summarize why we sign our names to work.
Explain that some old writings are lost.
Explain the Bibliographical Test (number of manuscripts).
Defend the criteria for authenticity in historical documents.
Solve simple word problems about time differences.
Analyze the value of oral history interviews.
Interpret a photograph as historical evidence.
Connect the artifact to the culture that made it.
Calculate the length of a person's life given birth and death years.
Analyze the duration of major empires (Roman vs. British).
Interpret time spans across the BC/AD divide.
Connect generations to time spans (approx. 40 years).
Compare travel by horse vs. car (Change) vs. needing to travel (Continuity).
Analyze the impact of the Industrial Revolution on daily life.
Interpret political continuity despite regime changes.
Connect human nature (sin/love) as a constant in history.
Compare the Stone Age with the Iron Age.
Analyze why historians choose specific dates to start/end periods.
Connect the Fall of Rome (476 AD) to the start of the Middle Ages.
Compare a King (lifetime) with a President (term).
Analyze the succession crisis (e.g., Henry VIII).
Interpret regnal years (dating by the king's reign).
Connect the rise and fall of dynasties to the Mandate of Heaven (China).
Compare BC/AD with BCE/CE (Common Era).
Analyze the transition point between BC and AD (no year 0).
Interpret century labels (e.g., 1900s is the 20th Century).
Connect the Gregorian Calendar to Christian history.
Compare the Russian Revolution with the American one.
Analyze the role of the Enlightenment in sparking change.
Interpret the consequences of violent vs. non-violent change.
Connect the printing press to the Reformation revolution.
Compare the Mongol Empire (land) with the British (sea).
Analyze the motives: God, Gold, Glory.
Interpret the cost of maintaining an empire (overstretch).
Connect technology (roads, ships) to expansion.
Compare Barter with Money.
Interpret the rise of Capitalism (Adam Smith).
Compare forced migration (slavery) with voluntary migration (Ellis Island).
Analyze Push and Pull factors.
Interpret the partition of India/Pakistan.
Connect urbanization to industrialization.
Compare immediate results with results 100 years later.
Analyze the 'Butterfly Effect' in history.
Interpret multi-causal events (e.g., Fall of Rome).
Connect the Treaty of Versailles to WWII.
Analyze the continuity of the Church through ages.
Interpret 'Progress' (is newer always better?).
Connect technology to social change.
Compare a hero with a celebrity.
Analyze why some events are recorded and others forgotten.
Interpret the criteria for significance (Remarkable, Resulting change, Revealing, Resonant).
Connect archaeology to verifying history.
Compare a diary entry with a newspaper article.
Analyze the 'Great Man Theory' vs. 'History from Below'.
Interpret Revisionist History.
Connect worldview to historical interpretation.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Corroboration and Cross-Referencing (The Rule of Witnesses)
objectives.objective_text: Compare two accounts of the same battle.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Corroboration and Cross-Referencing (The Rule of Witnesses)
objectives.objective_text: Analyze the reliability of a source based on corroboration.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Corroboration and Cross-Referencing (The Rule of Witnesses)
objectives.objective_text: Interpret the Synoptic Gospels as corroborated testimony.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Corroboration and Cross-Referencing (The Rule of Witnesses)
objectives.objective_text: Connect external evidence (archaeology) to written records.
Compare a Patriot's diary with a Loyalist's diary.
Analyze the intended audience of a document.
Interpret political cartoons for their bias.
Connect worldview assumptions to historical interpretation.
Compare an original painting with a copy.
Analyze the transmission history of a text.
Interpret the significance of the Dead Sea Scrolls.
Connect the time gap between event and writing to accuracy.
Compare the length of the USA's history with Ancient Egypt's.
Evaluate the "Telephone Game" effect in secondary literature.
Evaluate the perception of time in different cultures.
Evaluate the concept of 'Revolution' vs. 'Evolution' in society.
Evaluate the Eurocentric bias in standard periodization.
Evaluate the stability of hereditary monarchy vs. democracy.
Evaluate the maxim 'The revolution eats its own children'.
Evaluate the legacy of imperialism (language, borders).
Evaluate the morality of different economic systems (Socialism/Capitalism).
Evaluate the cultural enrichment vs. tension of migration.
Evaluate the weight of different causes (Economic vs. Ideological).
Evaluate the persistence of anti-semitism or other prejudices.
Evaluate the reliability of oral tradition.
Evaluate the Marxist view of history vs. the Christian view.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Corroboration and Cross-Referencing (The Rule of Witnesses)
objectives.objective_text: Evaluate the weight of hostile corroboration (when enemies agree).
Evaluate the utility of biased sources (learning what people believed).
Evaluate the impact of variants on historical understanding.
Evaluate the difficulty of dating ancient events precisely.
Connect the Dutch East India Company to modern stocks.
Construct a research paper relying on primary documents.
Analyze the impact of the Columbian Exchange on economics.
Construct a comparative timeline of concurrent civilizations.
Synthesize the 'longue dure' (long term) historical approach.
Synthesize the tension between tradition and innovation.
Synthesize the fluidity of historical transitions.
Construct a synchronized list of English Monarchs and major events.
Synthesize the narrative arc of a specific dynasty (e.g., The Habsburgs).
Construct a timeline spanning multiple millennia with accurate scaling.
Construct a comparative timeline of major revolutions.
Synthesize the cyclical nature of political upheaval.
Construct a theory on why empires fall (moral decay, debt, invasion).
Synthesize the translatio imperii (transfer of rule) concept.
Construct a map of historical trade routes.
Synthesize economic history with political power.
Construct a case study of a specific diaspora (e.g., Armenian, Chinese).
Synthesize demographic shifts with future geopolitical trends.
Construct a causal chain for a major historical event.
Synthesize God's sovereignty with human responsibility in history.
Construct an argument about a period of stagnation vs. rapid change.
Synthesize the 'Longue Dure' approach.
Construct a defense for the significance of an overlooked figure.
Synthesize historiography (the history of history writing).
Construct a balanced account of a controversial event.
Synthesize multiple perspectives to form a coherent narrative.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Corroboration and Cross-Referencing (The Rule of Witnesses)
objectives.objective_text: Construct a historical narrative using three conflicting sources.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Corroboration and Cross-Referencing (The Rule of Witnesses)
objectives.objective_text: Synthesize disparate accounts into a coherent whole.
Synthesize the "Court History" vs. the "People's History."
Construct a defense of the New Testament's textual integrity.
Synthesize textual criticism with historical reconstruction.
Summarize the three big ages: Ancient, Medieval, Modern.
Interpret the term 'Renaissance' as a transition.
Compare the Middle Ages with the Renaissance.
Synthesize archival research with modern scholarship.
Construct a case study on the persistence of religious belief amidst modernization.
Construct an argument for defining the 'Early Modern' period.
Synthesize different dating systems (Hebrew, Roman, Modern).
Construct a critique of a modern historical text for bias.
